Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Joshua H. Pollitz is " Homotopical Commutative Algebra and Support Varieties." The host institution for the fellowship University of Utah, and the sponsoring scientist is Srikanth B. Iyengar.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award allowed the PI to achieve excellence in research during their postdoc at the University of Utah. The PI's research is in commutative algebra and algebraic geometry, and relates to many other of pure mathematics like homotopy theory and representation theory. During the PI's postdoc, he was extremely active in various research collaborations. He wrote/worked on 14 papers during this time; 12 have been published so far and 2 are still being considered for publication. The published papers are all in high quality math journals (almost all of them are in general reputable journals, rather than specialist journals). The 2 that are still being considered for publication are submitted to very selective journals. 

The research has expanded our knowledge on singularities in commutative algebra using a wide array of homological techniques. There have several new insights that have led to some new advancements and have several future directions to pursue. Notable developments were in: 

  • Understanding singularities through structural properties of certain triangulated categories; esspecially the work on proxy-small objects, cohomological support, the homotopy Lie algebra, and revealing that high Frobenius pushforwards generate the derived category. 
  • Studying resolutions in various contexts, and giving a uniform explanation for such resolutions. This was done for a class of ring maps called Koszul, for modules differential operators over isolated singularity hypersurface rings, and for various differential graded algebra resolutions. 

The PI was also active as a mentor during the fellowship. On top of teaching advanced undergraduate classes at the University of Utah, the PI supervised many undergraduates on graduate level reading courses, and even served as one undergraduate's senior thesis mentor. The fellowship gave the PI the time to work with these undergraduates and prepare them for graduate school (all of them successfully were admitted to top schools of their choice).
